info: The filing enumerates membership classifications by region, industry sector, and contract type for FY2022 and FY2023, consistently reporting a total of 1,058,290 members across categories.

The company reports revolving credit facilities and unsecured debt, along with numerous foreign exchange contracts designated as cash flow hedging instruments and forward contracts, with maturities extending through 2026.

The filing lists multiple foreign‑exchange contracts, options and forward instruments designated as cash‑flow hedges for periods ending 2023‑2026, and notes fair‑value measurement levels for cash equivalents, short‑term investments and other current assets and liabilities.

The company reported a market value of $33.7 billion for non‑affiliate common shares on June 30 2024, based on a $68.00 per‑share price, and total Class A common shares outstanding of 494.6 million as of February 7 2025.

The registrant is not a shell company; its non‑affiliate voting equity was valued at $33.7 billion on June 30 2024 at $68 per share, and Class A common stock outstanding totaled 494.6 million shares as of February 7 2025.

The filing highlights extensive forward‑looking risk disclosures covering economic, geopolitical, competition, talent, AI adoption, client contract, regulatory and cyber risks. Cognizant’s strategy emphasizes accelerating AI‑enabled growth, expanding its partner ecosystem and modernizing operations, with recent acquisitions of Belcan and Thirdera in 2024 and the launch of the Cognizant Moment digital experience practice. It reorganizes its market approach from seven operating segments in 2024 to four reportable segments in 2025, and operates six integrated service practices.

Cognizant emphasized its AI‑driven Cognizant Moment practice, global delivery model and competitive positioning, while reporting a workforce of approximately 336,800 employees (241,500 in India) with 38% women, 47,000 volunteers, voluntary tech attrition decreasing to 15.9% in 2024, extensive upskilling of 277,000 employees and 168,000 completing generative AI training, and recognition in 20 countries for Great Place to Work.

The filing highlights leadership tenure, extensive risk factors including macroeconomic uncertainty, intense competition, AI investment risks, and significant skilled‑labor challenges, noting a rise in voluntary tech‑services attrition to 15.9% in 2024 from 13.8% in 2023, which could pressure margins and growth.

The company faces material risks from employee retention, short‑term client contracts, performance‑based fee structures, and cybersecurity threats, which could impair revenues and margins. Profitability and capital return depend on cost efficiencies, including the NextGen restructuring, while growth targets hinge on successful organic expansion and acquisitions. Additional uncertainties stem from foreign‑exchange volatility, pandemic disruptions, climate‑related events, and evolving ESG regulations.

The filing highlights heightened ESG and anti‑ESG regulatory risks, potential anti‑outsourcing legislation, and immigration visa constraints that could affect staffing and costs. Ongoing legal, tax and IP compliance exposures remain material, while the company reports no material cybersecurity incidents in 2024 and emphasizes its robust cyber risk management framework led by a CSO with 25 years of experience.

The Board oversees cybersecurity risk via the Audit Committee, with the CSO (25 years experience) reporting to senior legal leadership and coordinating with the CIO on security policy. Cognizant operates in nearly 50 countries with over 22 million square feet of facilities, 90% of delivery space in India (17 million sq ft). The company paid $0.30 quarterly dividends (total $1.20 in 2024) and announced a $0.31 dividend for 2025. It maintains a $11.5 billion stock repurchase program, with $1.237 billion remaining and $140 million repurchased in Q4 2024 (1.78 million shares at an average $78.71). Employee tax withholding purchases added 0.2 million shares at $14 million cost. Financially, revenue grew $383 million (+2.0%) with acquisitions contributing 200 bps; income from operations rose $203 million (+7.5%); adjusted operating margin improved 80 bps; diluted EPS increased $0.30 (+7.1%). The NextGen restructuring incurred $134 million in 2024, totalling $363 million since inception.

Revenue grew modestly by $383 million (2.0%) in 2024, driven by Health Sciences and North America while offset by weakness in Financial Services and Products & Resources. Acquisitions added 200 basis points to growth but are expected to be near‑term dilutive to margins. GAAP operating margin improved to 14.7% (up from 13.9%) and Adjusted margin to 15.3% (up from 15.1%). Voluntary attrition in Tech Services rose to 15.9% and headcount fell to 336,800. The company highlighted AI investment plans, macro‑economic and regulatory risks, and potential tax law impacts.

Revenue changes were driven by acquisitions (+200 bps overall, +600 bps in Products & Resources, +150 bps in Communications/Media/Tech) and resale of third‑party products (+70 bps), but offset by weaker discretionary demand and regional declines; restructuring charges fell to $134M from $229M, cost of revenues was $294M (0.3% of revenue) and SG&A $29M (0.5%); operating margin benefited from NextGen savings and foreign‑currency effects, with Indian rupee depreciation adding 44 bps; total segment operating profit rose modestly to $4.156B (21.1% of revenue) and net income increased to $114M, while other income fell to $46M due to forex losses and interest expense rose to $54M.

Operating income rose to $2.9 B in 2024 from $2.7 B in 2023, with adjusted operating margin improving to 15.3% from 15.1%. Net cash from operations fell to $2.1 B and free cash flow declined to $1.8 B. Cash balances stand at $2.24 B and $1.55 B of credit capacity remains. The company faces a $157 M tax transition payment due Q2 2025 and $1.1 B of purchase commitments, while DSO increased to 78 days.

The company expects its operating cash flows, cash balances, short‑term investments and credit facilities to cover operating needs, including a $157 million Tax Reform Act transition tax due in Q2 2025 and a $123 million payment made in 2024. It has $1.1 billion of purchase commitments over four years, $440 million of which are due in the next 12 months. Liquidity includes $1.031 billion of cash equivalents, $12 million of short‑term investments and a $1.85 billion revolving facility (with $300 million currently used) plus a $650 million term loan. Foreign‑exchange hedges cover $2.93 billion of notional exposure, with a $34 million unrealized loss and a $277 million sensitivity to a 10% rate move; balance‑sheet hedges total $489 million with a $1 million loss. The firm reported $29 million of foreign‑currency losses in 2024. Goodwill stands at $6.953 billion and was deemed not at risk of impairment. Revenue exposure to the UK, Europe and Rest of World accounts for 9.2%, 9.8% and 6.5% of 2024 revenues, while 24% of operating costs are in Indian rupees. Recent acquisition of Belcan represents 7.7% of assets and 1.5% of revenues.

Management concluded internal control over financial reporting was effective as of Dec 31, 2024, excluding Belcan which represented about 7.7% of assets and 1.5% of revenue following its Aug 26, 2024 acquisition. Director Michael Patsalos‑Fox adopted a Rule 10b5‑1 trading plan on Dec 13, 2024 to sell up to 25,000 shares, expiring Feb 20, 2026.

The filing lists numerous governance and financing exhibits, including the 2022 credit agreement and its amendment filed July 31 2024, the 2023 Incentive Award Plan, and a 2023 clawback policy, along with multiple stock award and employee stock purchase plan documents.

The audit report confirms that Cognizant’s consolidated financial statements for 2024 and 2023 present fairly, and internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31 2024. Management excluded the Belcan acquisition from its internal‑control assessment, noting Belcan represented 7.7% of total assets and 1.5% of total revenues. The filing was signed on February 12 2025 by the CEO, CFO, and board members.

The filing highlights a critical audit matter around revenue recognition for fixed‑price contracts, which represent $9.0 billion of 2024 revenue and require significant judgment on estimated labor costs. Internal control limitations are noted, and the auditor (PwC) has served since 1997. Financially, 2024 revenue modestly rose to $19.736 billion, net income increased to $2.240 billion, and total assets grew to $19.966 billion, while total liabilities and equity also rose.

Cognizant posted stable net income around $2.2 billion each year, growing retained earnings to $14.7 billion and total equity to $14.4 billion by year‑end 2024. The company continued regular dividend payouts, raising the per‑share dividend to $1.20 and paying roughly $600 million annually, while repurchasing a modest number of shares each year. Operating cash flow remained strong at about $2.1 billion in 2024, offset by significant investing outflows driven by $1.6 billion of business‑combination payments and modest financing cash uses, including $600 million of revolving‑credit borrowings and $300 million of repayments. Management highlighted ongoing emphasis on digital, AI‑enhanced services as a growth pillar.

Cognizant emphasizes its AI‑enhanced digital services and consulting focus within a seven‑segment operating model, outlines extensive lease accounting (excluding short‑term leases of 12 months or less) and cash management (cash equivalents maturing in 90 days or less), details revenue‑recognition methods and credit‑loss allowance practices, and notes a board‑approved stock repurchase program.

Company details its accounting policies on revenue recognition, contract assets/liabilities, credit loss allowances, capitalized costs, stock‑based compensation, foreign‑currency translation, derivative hedging, pension and post‑employment benefits, income‑tax provisions, EPS calculation (excluding <1 million anti‑dilutive shares), and restructuring charges, and notes recent accounting pronouncement adoptions with limited impact.

Revenue grew modestly to $19.736 billion in 2024, up from $19.353 billion in 2023 but slightly below 2022 levels. North America remained the primary market, contributing about $14.7 billion. Consulting and technology services continued to be the largest segment, while outsourcing services expanded modestly. The contract mix stayed weighted toward time‑and‑materials and fixed‑price agreements, with transaction‑based revenue remaining a small share.

Capitalized costs to fulfill decreased to $209 million in 2024 from $245 million in 2023, while contract assets grew to $386 million and deferred revenue rose to $480 million. Remaining performance obligations total $4.911 billion, with 35% expected within one year. The allowance for credit losses fell to $26 million after $12 million credit loss expense and $18 million write‑offs. 2024 saw sizable acquisitions: Belcan for $1.195 billion cash plus $113 million stock, and Thirdera for $428 million, contributing $384 million of acquisition‑related revenue. 2023 acquisitions added $130 million of revenue and $428 million of purchase price.

2023 acquisitions generated $130 million of revenue and the firm completed 2022 purchases of AustinCSI and Utegration with a total purchase price of $375 million. The NextGen restructuring program incurred $229 million of charges in 2023, driven by $115 million employee separation and $108 million facility exit costs. Year‑end 2023 investments comprised $14 million of short‑term and $435 million of long‑term holdings, including $74 million equity‑method and $6 million of non‑valued equity securities. Property and equipment net value was $1.048 billion in 2023, with depreciation expense of $390 million, $36 million of which related to restructuring. Lease‑related finance assets and software assets for sale also increased.

Software property and equipment balances rose to $338 million in 2024 from $279 million in 2023, with accumulated amortization increasing to $210 million. Software amortization expense was $36 million in 2024, unchanged from prior years. Operating lease assets and liabilities declined, with ROU operating‑lease assets falling to $552 million and total lease liabilities to $595 million in 2024. Operating lease costs dropped to $216 million in 2024 from $304 million in 2023, and variable lease costs fell to $23 million. Short‑term lease rental expense decreased to $11 million. Weighted average lease term is 5.3 years with a discount rate of 5.5%. Cash paid for operating‑lease liabilities was $251 million in 2024. Goodwill increased to $6.1 billion, total goodwill $6.95 billion, while intangible assets net $1.6 billion with amortization $188 million. Estimated amortization for 2025‑2029 ranges from $165‑$214 million.

Amortization expense for intangible assets is projected to decline from $214 million in 2025 to $165 million in 2029. Total accrued expenses rose to $2.61 billion in 2024 versus $2.425 billion in 2023, driven by higher compensation and benefits. The company operates under a $650 million term loan and a $1.85 billion revolving credit facility; $600 million was drawn in Q3 2024 and $300 million repaid in Q4 2024, leaving $300 million outstanding at year‑end. Debt covenants require a leverage ratio not above 3.5 × (3.75 × for up to four quarters post‑acquisition) and the firm was in compliance as of 12/31/2024. Short‑term debt was $33 million with interest rates of 5.3% (2024) and 6.3% (2023). Long‑term net debt increased to $875 million in 2024 from $606 million in 2023. Term loan maturities are $33 million in 2025, $33 million in 2026 and $544 million in 2027. Income before tax was $2.938 billion in 2024, and total provision for income taxes was $713 million (effective tax rate 24.3%). Ongoing Indian tax disputes relate to share‑repurchase transactions of $523 million (2013) and $2.8 billion (2016); deposits of $403 million (2024) and $60 million (2023) are held with the tax authority, with no reserves recorded.

The company reported net deferred tax assets of $1417 million (2024) and $985 million (2023) after a $48 million valuation allowance, with net deferred tax assets of $1094 million versus $767 million. Net operating loss carryforwards remain significant, with $131 million foreign and $83 million U.S. as of 2024. Unrecognized tax benefit balances increased to $319 million at year‑end 2024, driven by current‑year and prior‑year additions offset by statutory‑lapse reductions. Accrued interest and penalties total $35 million (2024). Derivative exposure includes $2 million of assets and $37 million of liabilities (2024), with cash‑flow hedge liabilities of $35 million. Expected reclassification of $16 million net loss from cash‑flow hedges within 12 months. Notional value of foreign‑exchange contracts stands at $2930 million (2024) versus $2898 million (2023), with $489 million notional and –$1 million fair value for other derivatives in 2024.

The company maintains foreign exchange forward contracts for hedging and non‑hedging purposes, with notional exposure decreasing to $489 million in 2024 from $1.317 billion in 2023. Net gains on non‑hedged forwards turned positive at $10 million in 2024 after a $40 million loss in 2023, while fair‑value of these contracts was modestly negative. Fair‑value assets are concentrated in money‑market funds ($40 million) and time deposits ($991 million) at Level 2, with small forward contract holdings. Significant OCI impacts include foreign‑currency translation losses (ending –$261 million) and cash‑flow hedge unrealized losses (ending –$34 million). Contingent consideration liabilities at Level 3 remained at $30 million, with payments of $30 million recorded in 2024.

The filing details multiple significant legal matters: the Syntel‑TriZetto dispute resulted in a $855 million verdict (later reduced to $570 million) with $285 million in attorney’s fees awarded; the award was partially vacated and the case is pending further proceedings. A $117 million accrual was recorded in 2019 for retroactive Indian employee contribution obligations, with uncertainty over final liability. Several shareholder derivative lawsuits have been dismissed, though one remains unresolved. A discrimination case led to a jury verdict favoring plaintiffs, with an estimated 2,300 affected former employees and potential punitive damages; no accruals have been recorded. These matters present material litigation and regulatory risks.

The company disclosed a retrial verdict in October 2024 favoring plaintiffs in a discrimination case, noting uncertainty about future individual claims and no accruals recorded; it also highlighted exposure to large liability claims despite insurance coverage. Significant employee benefit expenses were reported, including U.S. defined‑contribution contributions of $115 million (2024), India contributions of $151 million (2024), and other regions $104 million (2024). Pension liabilities stood at $63 million with periodic costs of $21 million (2024). Gratuity accruals were $80 million (2024) and related expenses $4 million. Stock‑based compensation expense was $175 million (2024) with an income‑tax benefit of $38 million, and unrecognized RSU and PSU costs of $146 million and $21 million respectively. Share‑based plans had 22.7 million incentive shares and 10.6 million purchase shares available for grant as of year‑end 2024, and the Purchase Plan issued 0.9 million shares in 2024.

The firm reports four reportable segments—Health Sciences, Financial Services, Products & Resources, and Communications, Media & Technology—with revenues of $19.7B, $19.4B and $19.4B in 2024, 2023 and 2022 respectively and segment operating profits ranging from $4.2B to $4.4B, indicating stable profitability; unallocated costs reduced income from operations each year. Long‑lived assets are concentrated in North America and India, totaling $994M, $1.048B and $1.101B for 2024‑2022. A $0.31 per share dividend was declared in February 2025.
